text:
Hey Katie!

No worries for the delay! Everything's going fine. Hope you're doing well!

Thanks for the link, really exciting! I'm planning to make a show-reel soon for it. Also, going to tweak CV and all of that lovely stuff.

Hey that's great to hear! Yeah woo it's been a roller coaster year for me so far... but work is coming along well - I think we may be announcing our project in the next few weeks/months which is exciting! I've been trying to do personal projects in my own time too because I'm thinking I want to move back into working in Film again after my current contract is up - so I need to show some improvement outside of work, because that is currently Non-Disclosure! It's a bit stressful but I am always motivated to work on my own stuff after a day of working on things that are assigned to me.. it's just having the discipline to actually finish a piece that I struggle with :grimacing:
Would be really lovely to see your show-reel, and if you need any help with CV stuff I can definitely help with that.
So in answer to your questions:

1. Jaw Blendshapes.
This question is a little bit advanced for me, I have only ever done animation at a level passable for previs and my blendshape work has all been for hacky/shot-sculpt type work. This article might help you get answers about this;
<https://www.creativebloq.com/how-to/how-to-rig-a-face-for-animation>
From my understanding, you want the jaw to be rigged to a skeleton in order to animate it, don’t depend on blendshapes alone.

attachments.title: How to rig a face for animation
attachments.text: Learn how to create a full facial rig with this workflow using Maya’s powerful utility nodes.
attachments.fallback: Creative Bloq: How to rig a face for animation

text:
2. Teeth, Tongue & Gums.
Again I think this is a question about facial animation, not blendshapes? I have never studied 3D animation so I don’t think I’m best to answer this question, I’m sorry!
You can definitely use Zbrush to set up your blendshape geometry though, providing it is all the same polycount - I think that’s a much better option than relying on 3D package sculpting tools.
I guess you would weight the teeth and gums to the jaw skeleton to keep it all synced up in 3D space - again, this question is probably better suited to animation or rigging people!

3. Cutting the Model.
No - you shouldn't need to cut the model apart, you can paint the weights of the area you want to blend using maps. This article explains it quite well: <https://knowledge.autodesk.com/support/maya/learn-explore/caas/CloudHelp/cloudhelp/2018/ENU/Maya-CharacterAnimation/files/GUID-950716A4-19CF-4C14-96F1-FD6B4D48663C-htm.html>

attachments.title: Paint blend shape weights | Maya 2018 | Autodesk Knowledge Network
attachments.text: With the Paint Blend Shape Weights Tool, you can use a Maya® Artisan™ brush to paint blend shape weights on an object that has a blend shape deformer (see Create blend shape deformers). This tool lets you set blend shape weights on a per vertex basis, giving you finer control over the amount of influence the target shapes have on the base shape. This tool also lets you paint the weights for each target shape, and lets you mix target shapes and create partial targets
attachments.fallback: Paint blend shape weights | Maya 2018 | Autodesk Knowledge Network

text: The script sounds fantastic by the way, it does seem very ambitious but I imagine as you are only really staying in one set that probably helps a lot? How long are you aiming the short to be? I'm really excited to see how it turns out! :monkey:
